title: 111_s2978
content: The Act titled "Renewing Hope for Haitian Trade and Investment Act of 2010" aims to improve trade facilitation efforts in Haiti. The Secretary of Homeland Security, through U.S. Customs and Border Protection, will allocate resources to enhance commercial assistance for trade between Haiti, the Dominican Republic, and the United States as outlined in the Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security will allocate resources to enhance commercial assistance for trade between Haiti, the Dominican Republic, and the United States. This includes facilitating the preclearance of valid cargo from Haiti to the US and providing technical assistance to improve customs procedures in Haiti. SEC. 3 of the Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act is amended to extend certain provisions until 2013. SEC. 4 extends the value-added rule of origin for apparel and textile articles imported from Haiti. Section 213A of the Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act is amended to redefine the term 'applicable 1-year period' and remove certain subparagraphs. Section 213A of the Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act is amended to redefine the term 'applicable 1-year period' and remove certain subparagraphs, including adjustments to the time periods specified in the clauses. Section 213A of the Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act is amended to redefine the term 'applicable 1-year period' and adjust time periods specified in clauses. The term 'applicable 1-year period' in Section 213A of the Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act is redefined for periods starting after December 20, 2012. The redefined 'applicable 1-year period' under Section 213A of the Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act has a corresponding percentage of 1 percent during the initial year and 1.25 percent for each subsequent year. In Section 213A of the Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act, the time frame is changed to December 19, 2013. Additionally, the percentage is adjusted to 1.25 percent for subsequent years. Subsections (c) and (h) are also modified to extend the time periods to 7 years and 2022 respectively. The "Haiti Recovery and Investment Task Force" is established to facilitate foreign direct investment, credit provision, remittances, and grants for Haiti's development. The "Haiti Recovery and Investment Task Force" is established to facilitate investment in Haiti and support its long-term development needs. The Task Force is composed of officials including the Secretary of the Treasury, the United States Trade Representative, the Secretary of Commerce, and the President of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. The Haiti Recovery and Investment Task Force, composed of key officials, shall convene public hearings and submit reports to Congress every 180 days on progress, obstacles, and recommendations for facilitating investment in Haiti. The Haiti Recovery and Investment Task Force will amend laws to facilitate investment in Haiti and will terminate 12 years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. GOVERNMENT ACCOUNTABILITY OFFICE REPORT ON THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE HOPE TRADE PREFERENCES. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report to Congress by May 31, 2010, assessing the effectiveness of trade preferences under the Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act for Haiti. Recommendations for improving these preferences, especially regarding trade expansion and employment post-earthquake, should be included.
